message: sometimes i hate Bundler... rm -rf .bundler Gemfile.lock is da favorite
so you still need something to redirect domain.com to www.domain.com or something
just got around to using rvm... very happy
RVM, Rails 3, Ruby 1.9.2, Slicehost... MongoDB has been the latest hotness for me.
@Stammy how do you load balance EC2? do you just put a haproxy EC2 instance in front?
i feel like i can turn out, count to 5 and Amazon will release a new web service in the meantime :p
tinkering with load balanced ec2 + rds + rails 3 + ruby 1.9.2 = nerdgasm
@dimitry well you are supposed to put the Gemfile.lock in your repo :)
@Stammy yup yup!
i thought it was a pain, but now i think it's not such a big deal...  only pain left is not being able to set root domain A record to an elb
Converting more of my rails business logic (model/controller) to services. Instead of constructing AR queries for different actions, I am calling internal APIS that can be used throughout the app
@dimitry i never had to do that yet. What do you do that makes that necessary?
http://aws.amazon.com/elasticloadbalancing/
@bryan yes, still only cname
@MSch its my quick solution to Bundler errors. have been getting a bunch of them in the last 2 weeks. like warnings of Gemfile.lock not being in my repo..
@dimitry oh didn't know that exists. that's very nice :)
i'm not really happy with Simple Email Service though, they rewrite too many headers for my liking. I prefer to supply my own message id. And they don't (yet) do DKIM signing.
Don't they still have that problem with only allowing CNAMEs to ELBs?
@dimitry what are ya working on these days? still DL?
its always in my repos :p thats the problem.
Elastic Load Balancer is definitely the way to go... it'll terminate your SSL cert too
if only there was a mongo instance on AWS so you could just attach to any new instance and not have to worry about firing it up
@stammy have you should try http://www.atmos.org/cinderella/ for your new dev setup. Been using it for my desktop and mobile, been pretty happy.
Do checkout http://planetrubyonrails.net/  Code here https://github.com/anildigital/planet
that could have really saved some time
According to Devise's github page the default is BCrypt, so that's cool. Maybe it still (weirdly) wants limited passwords.
@krainboltgreene we're using devise, could just be defaults we didn't override yet
good call on cinderella
we're testing out media-queries and some other candies on http://whyhello.im if anyone could take a minute and test it. please ;)
Still, crazy.
Now that's a great domain name pick, @alexbaldwin
we own helloworld.im too
@alexbaldwin: Password min 15, password max 20? That's ridiculous.
ah thanks
debating on which one to use
sorry about that, we're still working out the quirkiness
I'm pretty sure we're using BCrypt, but I believe there are limits in length by default. don't quote me though I'm a ruby n00b
Oh, woops. User name max : 15, password max: 20
@krainboltgreene woah that doesn't seem right, I know mine isn't that long
If you're storing/encrypting passwords correctly (BCrypt) then length shouldn't be an issue. If you're an "This is me" app, then username length shouldn't be an issue.
The second sentence is my opinion.
Checkout App to track exceptions from your Rails Apps. http://errorapp.com
TwitVance http://twitvance.com is my Twitter Scheduler application built using Rails.
@alexbaldwin whyhello.im looks a lot like about.me
they both look great, just wondering if you differentiate yourselves somehow

@choxi good question. they may look the same on the surface, but under the hood it's totally different. we rely on responsive design (so it looks sexy on iphone, ipad, desktop, whatever). our feature set is also heavily slanted towards developers, does about.me let you share your SSH or PGP keys?
also, we have bacon error messages http://whyhello.im/404
